meta.description:
Label Generation Rules for Montenegrin

Overview

This document specifies a reference set of Label Generation Rules for Montenegrin in the Cyrillic script using a limited repertoire as appropriate for a second level domain. The language code 'mxx' for Montenegrin is merely a placeholder. There is no ISO 639-2 code for that language. However the presence in the repertoire of two distinctive equivalents of Latin digraphs used exclusively for Montenegrin is, in itself, an argument for a separate identity from Serbian.

Repertoire

All references converge on 30 Cyrillic code points (23 +7 as defined by RFC 5992 [130]), identical to the Serbian set. There has been a recent addition of two letters unique to Montenegrin replacing the digraphs zj and sj. They are encoded as combining sequences: each is expressed by a consonant (U+0437 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER ZE or U+0441 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER ES), followed by U+0301 COMBINING ACUTE ACCENT. There is no need to include the combining mark separately in the repertoire.

There is no IDN table published in the IANA Repository of IDN Practices by a .me (Montenegro cctld).

The CLDR auxiliary set includes all code points to support Russian, but this is not supported by other sources, even for an extended set. In addition, there is some use of 6 vowels with double grave and inverted breve in Serbian phonology and poetics which would likely be shared with Montenegrin, but this use is not germane for IDNs.

Excluded code points

Letters documented in some references but not included:

  • U+0301 COMBINING ACUTE ACCENT

  • U+0449 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER SHCHA

  • U+044A CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER HARD SIGN

  • U+044B CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER YERU

  • U+044C CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER SOFT SIGN

  • U+044D CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER E

  • U+044E CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER YU

  • U+044F CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER YA

  • U+0451 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER IO

  • U+0430 U+030F CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER A WITH DOUBLE GRAVE ACCENT

  • U+0430 U+0311 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER A WITH INVERTED BREVE

  • U+0435 U+030F CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER IE WITH DOUBLE GRAVE ACCENT

  • U+0435 U+0311 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER IE WITH INVERTED BREVE

  • U+0438 U+030F CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER I WITH DOUBLE GRAVE ACCENT

  • U+0438 U+0311 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER I WITH INVERTED BREVE

  • U+043E U+030F CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER O WITH DOUBLE GRAVE ACCENT

  • U+043E U+0311 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER O WITH INVERTED BREVE

  • U+0440 U+030F CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER ER WITH DOUBLE GRAVE ACCENT

  • U+0440 U+0311 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER ER WITH INVERTED BREVE

  • U+0443 U+030F CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER U WITH DOUBLE GRAVE ACCENT

  • U+0443 U+0311 CYRILLIC SMALL LETTER U WITH INVERTED BREVE

Extended code points

None.

Variants

None.

Character Classes

This LGR defines no named character classes.

Rules

Common rules only:

  • Hyphen Restrictions — restrictions on the allowable placement of hyphens (no leading/ending hyphen and no hyphen in positions 3 and 4). These restrictions are described in section 4.2.3.1 of RFC5891 [120]. They are implemented here as context rule on U+002D (-) HYPHEN-MINUS.

  • Leading Combining Marks — restrictions on the allowable placement of combining marks (no leading combining mark). This rule is described in section 4.2.3.2 of RFC5891 [120].

Actions

Actions included are the default actions for LGRs as well as those needed to invalidate labels with misplaced combining marks.

Variant-related actions included to facilitate integration as appropriate.

Methodology and Contributors

This reference LGR for Montenegrin for the 2nd Level has been developed by Michel Suignard and Asmus Freytag, verified in expert reviews by Michael Everson, Nicholas Ostler, and Wil Tan, and based on multiple open public consultations.

References

General reference for the language:

  • Browne, Wayles. 1993. "Serbo-Croat", in Bernard Comrie & Greville G. Corbett, eds. The Slavonic languages. London; New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-04755-2

In the listing of the repertoire by code point, references starting from [0] refer to the version of the Unicode Standard in which the corresponding code point was initially encoded. Other references, (starting from [100]) document usage of code points. For more details, see the Table of References below.

reference.comment: Any code point cited was originally encoded in Unicode Version 1.1

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium. The Unicode Standard, Version 6.3.0, (Mountain View, CA: The Unicode Consortium, 2013. ISBN 978-1-936213-08-5)
Ministry of Science and Education, Montenegro, page 8 http://www.gov.me/files/1248442673.pdf
RFC5891, Internationalized Domain Names in Applications (IDNA): Protocol http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5891
RFC5992, Internationalized Domain Names Registration and Administration Guidelines for European Languages Using Cyrillic - section 2.6 Montenegrin https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5992

reference.comment: Code points cited form the standard set

references.reference: Everson, Michael, The Alphabets of Europe, Serbian http://www.evertype.com/alphabets/montenegrin.pdf

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the set of Main Letters

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository - CLDR Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for Montenegrin [sr_ME]- http://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/sr.html

reference.comment: Code points cited are from the set of Auxiliary Letters

references.reference: The Unicode Consortium, Common Locale Data Repository - CLDR Version 28 (2015-09-16) - Locale Data Summary for Montenegrin [sr_ME]- http://www.unicode.org/cldr/charts/28/summary/sr.html

rule.name: leading-combining-mark
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of combining marks

rule.name: hyphen-minus-disallowed
rule.comment: RFC5891 restrictions on placement of U+002D
no consecutive hyphens in third and fourth

rule.name: extended-cp
rule.comment: code points from the extended range

action.comment: by default, labels with leading combining marks are invalid
